bibl.title: The Medical and Surgical History of the War of the Rebellion. (1861–65.)
bibl.editor: Surgeon General Joseph K. Barnes, United States Army

taxonomy.bibl: Medical and Surgical History of the War of the Rebellion

keywords.term: wounds and injuries of the spine
gunshot injuries of the lumbar vertebræ
gunshot fractures of the apophyses of the lumbar spine
musket-ball fractures of the third lumbar vertebra
ball lodged between arches of second and third lumbar vertebræ
ball partially in spinal canal, injuring spinal cord

revisionDesc.change: additional proofing of transcription and encoding
case text extracted and transformed from larger file
initial checking of OCR text against PDF; encoded

body.p: CASE.—Private Elias H——, Co. E, 149th Pennsylvania Volunteers, aged 40 years, was wounded on May 8th, 1864, and, on the 18th, was admitted to Douglas Hospital, Washington, in a paraplegic condition, and died a few hours after. A conoidal musket ball had entered over the lower ribs of the left side, and, passing deeply in the muscles of the abdomen, lodged between the arches of the second and third lumbar vertebra vertebræ and partially in the spinal canal, injuring the cord. The bladder was distended. The pathological specimen was contributed to the Army Medical Museum by Assistant Surgeon W. Thomson, U. S. A. It is represented in the adjoining wood-cut (FIG. 199)

figure.head: FIG. 199.—Third and fourth lumbar vertebræ, with a ball lodged between their arches and projecting into the canal.Spec. 3523, Sect. I, A. M. M.
